# The `MCSymbol` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcsymbol">MCSymbol</a> - Instances of this class represent a symbol name in the MC file, and MCSymbols are created and uniqued by the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mccontext">MCContext</a> class. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Declaration

<CodeBlock>class llvm::MCSymbol</CodeBlock>

## Description {#details}

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcsymbol">MCSymbol</a> - Instances of this class represent a symbol name in the MC file, and MCSymbols are created and uniqued by the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mccontext">MCContext</a> class.

MCSymbols should only be constructed with valid names for the object file.

If the symbol is defined/emitted into the current translation unit, the Section member is set to indicate what section it lives in. Otherwise, if it is a reference to an external entity, it has a null section.

Definition at line 41 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/mc/mcsymbol-h">MCSymbol.h</a>.

<SectionDefinition>

## Protected Member Typedefs

### NameEntryStorageTy {#acc9e4586713b5561ff4a0daf55d476fc}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>using llvm::MCSymbol::NameEntryStorageTy =  union &#123;
    const MCSymbolTableEntry &#42;NameEntry;
    uint64&#95;t AlignmentPadding;
  &#125;</>}
  labels = {["protected"]}>
The name for a symbol.

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mcsymbol">MCSymbol</a> contains a uint64&#95;t so is probably aligned to 8. On a 32-bit system, the name is a pointer so isn&#39;t going to satisfy the 8 byte alignment of uint64&#95;t. Account for that here.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/mc/mcsymbol-h/#l00159">159</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/mc/mcsymbol-h">MCSymbol.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>

## Enumerations

### anonymous enum  {#a454d311b0ae2e3bdac7d581e79062f4f}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="anonymous enum : unsigned"
 labels = {["protected"]}>
The alignment of the symbol if it is &#39;common&#39;.

<EnumerationList title="Enumeration values">

<Link id="a454d311b0ae2e3bdac7d581e79062f4fac8ece6378cbe9f0340ed2cfc60c19616" />
<EnumerationListItem name="NumCommonAlignmentBits">
 (= 5)
</EnumerationListItem>

</EnumerationList>

Internally, this is stored as log2(align) + 1. We reserve 5 bits to encode this value which allows the following values 0b00000 -&gt; unset 0b00001 -&gt; 1ULL &lt;&lt; 0 = 1 0b00010 -&gt; 1ULL &lt;&lt; 1 = 2 0b00011 -&gt; 1ULL &lt;&lt; 2 = 4 ... 0b11111 -&gt; 1ULL &lt;&lt; 30 = 1 GiB

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/mc/mcsymbol-h/#l00129">129</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/mc/mcsymbol-h">MCSymbol.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### Fragment {#aacd0cd49830dc61d53ea13f8a02865da}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>MCFragment&#42; llvm::MCSymbol::Fragment = nullptr</>}
  labels = {["protected", "mutable"]}>
If a symbol has a Fragment, the section is implied, so we only need one pointer.

The special AbsolutePseudoFragment value is for absolute symbols. If this is a variable symbol, this caches the variable value&#39;s fragment. FIXME: We might be able to simplify this by having the asm streamer create dummy fragments. If this is a section, then it gives the symbol is defined in. This is null for undefined symbols.

If this is a fragment, then it gives the fragment this symbol&#39;s value is relative to, if any.
